intro: Alberta loranthoides f. latisepala, commonly known as the broad-sepaled mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of its host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its leaf-like stems and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant's inflorescences are typically clustered and produce small, fleshy fruits that are dispersed by birds. It is native to the mountainous regions of Alberta, Canada, and thrives in temperate climates. Its parasitic nature allows it to draw water and nutrients from the host, while also contributing to the ecological dynamics of its environment.
